item.title: You Can Preload the Battlefield 6 Beta Right Now
item.description:
Battlefield 6 preloads are now available for the game’s upcoming Open Beta, with players able to prepare themselves ahead of time by downloading the beta client ahead of its earliest start date of August 7. While doing this, it’s important to note the Open Beta for Battlefield 6 will be available first for Early Access players, before later becoming available to all players starting August 9.

The Open Beta for Battlefield 6 will be available on platforms including Xbox, PlayStation, and PC via Steam and Epic Games. Before jumping in, PC players are encouraged to review the system requirements for Battlefield 6 to ensure they get the best experience possible. It’s also worth brushing up on the inclusion of EA’s proprietary Javelin anti-cheat system, which it recently confirmed will be present in Battlefield 6 at launch.

The Battlefield 6 Open Beta is Now Available to Preload

Gamers interested in checking out Battlefield 6 can preload the Open Beta starting August 4 on all platforms ahead of its Early Access start time of August 7 at 8:00 a.m. PT (3:00 p.m. UTC). For those who don’t qualify for the Early Access period, the earliest start time for the Open Beta will be August 9 at 1:00 a.m. PT (8:00 a.m. UTC). To begin preloading, all players need to do is navigate to the game’s page on their platform of choice and locate the necessary button to download the playtest. Currently, preloads for Battlefield 6 are available through the EA App, PC via Steam and Epic Games, along with Xbox and PlayStation storefronts.

  • Preload Start: August 4, 8:00 a.m. PT (3:00 p.m. UTC)
  • Early Access: August 7, 1:00 a.m. PT (8:00 a.m. UTC)
  • First Open Beta Weekend: August 9, 1:00 a.m. PT (8:00 a.m. UTC)
  • Second Open Beta Weekend: August 14, 1 a.m. PT (8:00 a.m. UTC)

To preload Battlefield 6 , players will need to allot the necessary amount of space, with the download size at 39.3 GB through the EA App, 35.7 GB on PC via Steam, 37.56 GB for Xbox Series X, and 33.91 for PlayStation 5. It’s also recommended by the developer for players to link their EA account to the platform where they’ll be participating in the Open Beta if they haven’t done so already. According to EA, each Open Beta weekend for Battlefield 6 will give players the opportunity to earn exclusive rewards that will be available in the game at launch.

Siege of Cairo, Liberation Peak, and Iberian Offensive will be the maps of focus for the first weekend of the Open Beta, while the second weekend will see the addition of Empire State. Modes for the first weekend include Conquest, Breakthrough, Closed Weapons Breakthrough, Domination, and King of the Hill, with the second weekend adding Rush and Squad Deathmatch. As for weapons, according to DICE Producer, Alexia Christofi, Battlefield 6 will feature significantly more weapons at launch than are currently available in the Open Beta.

The exact number will be closer to 40 available weapons versus the original pool of 22 weapons that launched in Battlefield 2042 . DICE has also clarified what Battlefield 6's approach to matchmaking will be, confirming that while skill-based matchmaking (SBMM) will be present, it will play a lesser role in large-scale modes like Conquest compared to smaller modes like Team Deathmatch.

item.title: Best Open-World Games To Just Chill
item.description:
Summary

  • Slime Rancher 2 offers cute, stress-free farming with low levels of pressure within a visually soothing world.
  • Breath of the Wild balances serene exploration, light combat, and freedom of choice with a calming atmosphere.
  • No Man's Sky provides cosmic exploration without stress, focusing on discovery and beauty over urgency or threats.

The open-world genre is often associated with sprawling quests, chaotic combat, and high-stakes exploration, but not every game pushes the player to the limits or expects them to fight non-stop from start to finish. A growing corner of the genre offers players something different, with a chance to relax and immerse themselves in calm, beautiful environments without pressure or urgency.

Whether it's through gentle exploration, cozy farming, or quiet storytelling, these titles transform vast digital spaces into places of peace. They prioritize atmosphere over action, and comfort over challenge, helping players unwind and maybe even breathe a little deeper at the same time.

Slime Rancher 2

A Colorful Farming Sim With Plenty Of Cuteness

3 Images
3 Images
Slime Rancher 2
Adventure
Systems
Released
September 23, 2025

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL

ESRB
E10+ For Everyone 10+ Due To Fantasy Violence
Developer(s)
Monomi Park
Platform(s)
PC, Xbox Series X, Xbox Series S, PlayStation 5
Powered by

Slime Rancher 2 is undeniably upbeat and colorful, providing players with a cute management simulator that never strays too far into the realm of pressure. Players collect bouncy, adorable slimes and expand their ranch, all in a candy-colored landscape that’s visually soothing. The small inventory juggling mechanics and other demands add a level of interactivity that keeps things interesting and low stress at all times.

Its whimsical design and bubbly energy ensure that nothing ever feels truly stressful, and the exploration is encouraged but never forced. The creatures are charming companions rather than challenges, making it perfect for those who like their chill time to involve light goals and constant cuteness in a world that feels straight out of a kid's imagination.

The Legend Of Zelda: Breath Of The Wild

Expansive Landscapes Waiting To Be Discovered

The Legend of Zelda: Breath of the Wild
10 /10
46
9.2 /10
Released
March 3, 2017

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
E for Everyone: Fantasy Violence, Use of Alcohol, Mild Suggestive Themes
Developer(s)
Nintendo EPD
Platform(s)
Nintendo Wii U, Nintendo Switch, Nintendo Switch 2
OpenCritic Rating
Mighty
Powered by

Breath of the Wild is a great game to kick back with, thanks to its unrivaled serenity and the ambient piano score that sets a tone of quiet exploration while offering some combat encounters in between. Climbing cliffs, gliding through valleys, and cooking meals over a fire are as central as fighting monsters, but even when players do decide to take on one of the many enemies, they will never feel tested too much.

The game’s freedom allows players to completely avoid conflict if desired. Its open-ended structure also means there’s no rush or pressure - just the open sky and endless paths to explore. For gamers drawn to discovery and introspection, Hyrule can become a personal retreat from the noise of the real world.

No Man's Sky

Cosmic Exploration Without The Stress

5 Images
5 Images
No Man's Sky
7 /10
61
9.3 /10
Released
August 9, 2016

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
T for Teen: Fantasy Violence, Animated Blood
Developer(s)
Hello Games
Platform(s)
PlayStation 5, PlayStation 4, Xbox Series X, Xbox Series S, Xbox One, Nintendo Switch, PC, Nintendo Switch 2
OpenCritic Rating
Fair
Powered by

With the introduction of Creative and Relaxed modes, No Man’s Sky transformed from a survival-heavy grind into a serene cosmic simulator. Players can now explore alien planets, collect unusual flora and fauna, or build elaborate bases with zero threats. Jumping between galaxies feels meditative, especially when accompanied by soothing ambient music and glowing, surreal landscapes straight out of a science fiction novel.

Although its systems can still appear complex at first glance, the lack of urgency makes the No Man's Sky experience deeply calming. There’s always something beautiful to discover, but there is no expectation to do anything at all. It's a galaxy that asks nothing of the player but to look around and breathe it all in.

Sable

Rewarding Exploration Minus The Combat

Sable
8 /10
9.0 /10
Released
September 23, 2021

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL

ESRB
e
Developer(s)
Shedworks
Platform(s)
PC, PS5, PS4, Xbox One, Xbox Series X, Xbox Series S
OpenCritic Rating
Strong
Powered by

Sable invites players into a beautifully stylized desert landscape where combat and danger are completely absent. Instead, the focus is on exploration, personal discovery, and quiet contemplation, as players traverse a painterly world by hoverbike, uncovering the remnants of ancient civilizations.

The game’s cel-shaded art direction and ambient soundtrack contribute to a deeply calming atmosphere. Dialogue is thoughtful, and the pacing is entirely player-driven, as the game isn’t just about going somewhere; it's about appreciating the space in between, making it one of the most meditative and emotionally resonant open-world titles available.

Minecraft

An Entire Sandbox For Limitless Creativity

6 Images
6 Images
Minecraft
191
9.0 /10
Released
November 18, 2011

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL

ESRB
E10+ For Everyone 10+ Due To Fantasy Violence
Developer(s)
Mojang
Platform(s)
3DS, Android, iOS, Nintendo Switch, Nintendo Wii U, PC, PlayStation 3, PlayStation 4, PS Vita, Xbox One, Xbox 360
OpenCritic Rating
Mighty
Powered by

Minecraft is a playground for creativity that gives players all the tools they need to build and survive in what is an incredibly forgiving and open-ended universe. Players are free to explore caves, build sprawling castles, or simply wander forests without ever worrying too much, and with peaceful mode enabled, the relaxation becomes elevated to new heights.

The pace is entirely self-directed, which can occasionally feel aimless to some, but the ability to shape the world at will is a powerful tool for calming the mind. Whether building a quiet cottage by a lake or tending to crops in the morning sun, Minecraft offers tranquility on the player’s own terms.

Lake

Scenic Routes Along A Quiet Road

Lake
Adventure
Systems
Released
September 1, 2021

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL

ESRB
M For Mature 17+ Due To Strong Language, Use of Drugs
Developer(s)
Gamious
Platform(s)
PC, PS4, PS5, Xbox One, Xbox Series X, Xbox Series S
OpenCritic Rating
Fair
Powered by

Lake places players in the shoes of Meredith Weiss, a postal worker spending a few weeks back in her hometown. The gameplay is delightfully simple, as players drive a mail truck, deliver packages, and chat with neighbors at a pace that is intentionally slow. The stakes are non-existent, and the story unfolds at a steady, thoughtful rhythm in a world full of beauty and serenity.

It plays more like a slice-of-life sim, emphasizing connection and small moments. Throughout the game, the player defines the tone of their journey, resulting in it becoming a love letter to quiet, overlooked days. All of this combined makes Lake one of the most low-stress open-world experiences available.

A Short Hike

Simplistic Areas With Plenty Of Charm

A Short Hike
8.5 /10
Released
April 5, 2019

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL

ESRB
E For Everyone
Developer(s)
Adam Robinson-Yu
Platform(s)
PC, PS4, Switch, Xbox One
OpenCritic Rating
Mighty
Powered by

A Short Hike is exactly what its name suggests: a small, open-world hike filled with charm where players are free to wander at will, chat with quirky characters, collect trinkets, and glide through the air without a care in the world. There are no fail states or time pressure; there is only a world that encourages curiosity without the intensity found in other titles in the open-world genre.

Its cozy pixel art and whimsical tone give it the warmth of a friendly campfire story, and despite being brief, it creates a lasting sense of peace that will leave most players smiling, not from adrenaline, but from the quiet joy that will continue to remain long after the game ends.

Eastshade

Nature, Art, And Emotional Solitude

3 Images
3 Images
Eastshade
9.3 /10
Released
February 13, 2019

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL

ESRB
E10+ For Everyone 10+ // Mild Language, Use of Alcohol
Developer(s)
Eastshade Studios
Platform(s)
PC, PlayStation 4, Xbox One
OpenCritic Rating
Strong
Powered by

Eastshade offers something rare in gaming, which is an open world built entirely around beauty and expression. Players explore a tranquil island as a traveling painter, capturing landscapes on a canvas and uncovering emotional narratives, all without combat or violence. The art mechanic itself encourages players to stop and observe rather than rush ahead, giving them plenty of opportunities to soak in the landscape and enjoy the sights.

Its visual palette of misty forests and golden fields evokes the feel of a walking meditation. Every inch of Eastshade feels designed to slow the player down and remind them to watch the sunrise or pause under the trees. By not compelling the player to take on long, challenging quests or ridiculous fights, it delivers a relaxing, contemplative journey for them to get lost in.

item.title: Horror Games That Didn't Live Up To The Hype But Are Still Worth Playing
item.description:
Summary

  • Hype can make or break horror games: anticipation can lead to triumphs, but over-hyping without execution spells trouble for developers.
  • Despite disappointments, many horror games offer unique and memorable experiences worth revisiting.
  • Titles like The Evil Within 2, The Medium, and Call of Cthulhu manage to deliver distinct experiences amid mixed reviews and rocky starts.

In the horror genre, hype can be a double-edged sword for a game's success, as a healthy amount of anticipation can lead to huge triumphs, while an over-hyped product without the polish to execute on its promise can be a significant problem for the developer.

Yet even among a slew of disappointments and troubled launches, many titles still manage to deliver distinctive and memorable horror experiences that are worth revisiting. Whether through atmosphere or intriguing storylines, there are so many gems in the genre that are hiding behind mixed reviews or a shoddy start that overshadowed the actual greatness of the game.

The Evil Within 2

Survival Horror That Leans Heavily Into The Psychological

The Evil Within 2
9 /10
7.7 /10
Released
October 13, 2017

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
M For Mature 17+ due to Blood and Gore, Intense Violence, Partial Nudity, Strong Language
Developer(s)
Tango Gameworks
Platform(s)
PS4, Xbox One, PC
OpenCritic Rating
Strong
Powered by

The Evil Within 2 had the difficult task of following up the uneven but ambitious original by providing something new to the series while keeping the DNA that made the first game so good intact. Marketed as a major evolution in horror storytelling and design, the sequel leaned into a semi-open world structure that clashed with expectations for tightly scripted scares.

Despite that, the game remains a highly worthwhile horror experience, thanks to its psychological themes and grounded emotional core, lending it a surprisingly deep narrative. The surreal environments and effective set pieces make it a standout in the genre, and while it didn’t quite redefine horror, it offered a haunting and memorable journey for those who looked beyond the marketing.

The Medium

Split Realities In A Dark, Gloomy World

The Medium
8 /10
8.0 /10
Released
January 28, 2021

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
M for Mature: Blood, Strong Language, Violence
Developer(s)
Bloober Team
Platform(s)
PC, Xbox Series X, Xbox Series S
OpenCritic Rating
Strong
Powered by

The Medium gained attention for its dual-reality mechanic and promise of psychological horror inspired by Silent Hill . However, upon release, its gameplay was relatively limited, with passive puzzle-solving, light stealth, and little interactivity. Alongside this, the horror itself was restrained, focusing more on tone than outright fear, which left some fans wanting more intensity.

Even so, The Medium offers a compelling narrative and a masterfully crafted atmosphere that not only serves as a technical achievement but also supports the thematic depth of trauma and loss. Combined with a haunting score and an exploration of some darker themes, it delivers a uniquely somber and reflective take on horror, despite its shortcomings.

Call Of Cthulhu

Cosmic Horrors With Plenty Of Puzzles To Solve

Call of Cthulhu
4 /10
8.5 /10
Released
October 30, 2018

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

Developer(s)
Cyanide Studio
Platform(s)
Nintendo Switch, PC, PlayStation 4, Xbox One
OpenCritic Rating
Fair
Powered by

Expectations were high for Call of Cthulhu , an adaptation of Lovecraftian horror that aimed to blend detective mechanics with cosmic dread. While the final release managed to capture the oppressive mood of the source material, it faltered mechanically. Clunky stealth segments and inconsistent pacing dampened its ability to fully immerse players in its universe, and the overall reception ranged from mildly positive to a complete disregard for the title.

Still, the game excels in its narrative and tone, with the decaying environments and slow-burn descent into paranoia aligning well with Lovecraft’s original vision. Its branching dialogue and investigative structure lend weight to player choices, and the game succeeds in conjuring a unique form of horror, one built not on jump scares but on psychological decay and existential unease.

Observer: System Redux

Cyberpunk Horror Wrapped In A City Of Decay

Observer: System Redux
8.5 /10
Released
November 10, 2020

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL

ESRB
M For Mature 17+ Due To Blood and Gore, Intense Violence, Partial Nudity, Sexual Content, Strong Language, Use of Drugs
Developer(s)
Bloober Team
Platform(s)
PC, Xbox Series X, PS5
OpenCritic Rating
Strong
Powered by

Observer aimed to merge cyberpunk aesthetics with psychological horror, and it succeeded artistically, but it wasn’t the mainstream breakthrough some hoped for. Its sluggish pacing and abstract narrative design left some players disoriented or disengaged, keeping a lot of the appeal in a more niche segment of the market.

Yet as a horror experience, the game offers something rare. The world is one of the most vividly realized in horror, and the performances of the characters add a layer of gravitas to a deeply introspective narrative. The game’s haunting dream sequences, visuals, and commentary on surveillance culture combine to create an unsettling, cerebral experience that rewards patience and observation.

The Callisto Protocol

Gory Space Horrors From A Genre Veteran

The Callisto Protocol
7 /10
8.3 /10
Released
December 2, 2022

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
M for Mature: Blood and Gore, Intense Violence, Strong Language
Developer(s)
Striking Distance Studios
Platform(s)
PC, PlayStation 4, PlayStation 5, Xbox One, Xbox Series S, Xbox Series X
OpenCritic Rating
Fair
Powered by

Marketed as the spiritual successor to Dead Space , The Callisto Protocol generated immense anticipation. However, the game suffered from an uneven launch, with technical issues and design choices that frustrated players, especially its heavy reliance on melee combat and repetitive enemy encounters. Its short runtime and lack of innovation left many feeling underwhelmed after what was supposed to be a return to greatness.

Despite these flaws, the game delivers a brutal and atmospheric horror experience full of grotesque creature design and environmental details. The oppressive prison-planet setting builds an authentic sense of isolation, and the game’s gruesome tone is consistent throughout. Though it failed to match its ambitious comparisons, it still offers a compelling sci-fi horror experience that deserves recognition on its own terms.

Amnesia: Rebirth

Trading Cheap Scares For A Haunting Story

Amnesia: Rebirth
9 /10
8.0 /10
Released
October 20, 2020

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL

ESRB
M For Mature 17+ due to Blood and Gore, Intense Violence, Nudity, Strong Language
Developer(s)
Frictional Games
Platform(s)
PS4, PC
OpenCritic Rating
Strong
Powered by

Amnesia: Rebirth followed in the footsteps of one of the most influential horror games of the 2010s. With that legacy came expectations for intense fear and innovative design, but instead, Rebirth leaned heavily into storytelling, with fewer scares and more slow-paced exploration, which for some was a letdown.

However, this change in focus allowed the game to explore deeper emotional and existential themes. Set in a desolate desert filled with forgotten ruins and ancient horrors, the game uses its setting and story to craft a feeling of dread rooted in identity, memory, and loss. It trades panic for sorrow and shock for despair, proving that horror can be just as powerful when it’s quieter and more narratively driven.

Silent Hill: Downpour

A Troubled Return To A Legendary Series

Silent Hill: Downpour
Survival Horror
Systems
7 /10
8.0 /10
Released
March 13, 2012
ESRB
M For Mature 17+ // Blood and Gore, Intense Violence, Sexual Themes, Strong Language

Developer(s)
Vatra Games
Platform(s)
PlayStation 3, Xbox 360
Powered by

As the last mainline Silent Hill title before the franchise went dormant, Downpour arrived with heavy expectations. With so much weight on its shoulders, having technical issues and awkward combat left fans divided, as many felt it lacked the polish and psychological edge that defined earlier entries in the series.

Yet the game still contains flashes of Silent Hill ’s signature brilliance. The game’s rain-drenched town is oppressive and haunting, with a strong visual design and a commitment to surrealism. Its story tackles themes of guilt and redemption with surprising depth, and certain side quests reflect the series’ tradition of personal, twisted horror. While far from perfect, it remains an ambitious and underappreciated entry in one of horror's most iconic franchises.

item.title: All Grow a Garden Cooking Recipes
item.description:
With the 1.17.0 update in Grow a Garden , players can cook different items for Chris P. every hour to earn rewards of varying rarities. This NPC is a critter chef who craves one specific meal every 60 minutes, and his cravings reset hourly.

All you need to do is prepare the item by tossing ingredients into the cooking pot. There are almost 12 food cravings Chris P. can have , and each has multiple working recipes. Below is a list of all the tested combinations. Normal recipes can reward anything from Uncommon to Mythical rarity, while Divine and Prismatic versions have a better chance of scoring higher-tier rewards from Chris P.'s Kitchen.

All Grow a Garden Cooking Recipes

All Cooking Event Cravings

Normal Recipes

Divine Recipes

Prismatic Recipes

Soup

1 Sugar Apple + 1 Ember Lily

-

-

Sushi

4 Bamboos + 1 Corn

1 Bamboo + 1 Corn + 3 Bone Blossoms

-

Pizza

1 Coconut + 1 Cactus + 1 Corn

1 Bone Blossom + 1 Sugar Apple + 1 Corn

3 Bone Blossoms + 1 Sugar Apple + 1 Violet Corn

Burger

1 Pepper + 1 Corn + 1 Tomato

3 Bone Blossoms + 1 Corn + 1 Tomato

3 Bone Blossoms + 1 Corn + 1 Tomato

Sandwich

2 Tomatoes + 1 Corn

2 Bone Blossoms + 2 Elder Strawberries + 1 Tomato

-

Hotdog

1 Pepper+ 1 Corn

4 Ember lilies + 1 Corn

4 Bone Blossoms + 1 Banana

Cake

2 Strawberries + 1 Banana + 1 Ember lily

4 Sugar Apples + 1 Corn

3 Bone Blossoms + 1 Banana + 1 Sugar Apple

Ice Cream

1 Corn + 1 Blueberry, Strawberry, or Banana

1 Sugar Apple + 1 Sugarglaze

-

Donut

1 Corn + 1 Blueberry + 1 Strawberry

1 Bone Blossom + 1 Sugar Apple + 1 Banana

1 Sugarglaze + 4 Bone Blossoms

Waffle

1 Coconut + 1 Strawberry

1 Sugar Apple + 1 Coconut

3 Bone Blossoms + 1 Sugar Apple + 1 Pumpkin

Pie

1 Pumpkin + 1 Apple

3 Bone Blossoms + 1 Sugar Apple + 1 Banana

3 Bone Blossoms + 1 Sugar Apple + 1 Coconut

Salad

2 Tomatoes + 1 Corn

3 Sugar Apples + 1 Pepper + 1 Pineapple

4 Bone Blossoms + 1 Tomato

Soup is the easiest recipe; you can make it using random items. Even if you have nothing expensive, just dropping Carrots can give you a Very Common Soup.

Players can still give Chris P. different meals outside his specific cravings. For example, if he's asking for Cake, you can still hand him Soup, but the rewards might vary. Also, adding bigger fruits not only boosts your chances for better rewards but also increases the size of your meal.

item.title: Nintendo Switch 2 Cartridges May Be Changing
item.description:
Nintendo Switch 2 could eventually have game cartridges offering different storage sizes. At present, the Switch 2 developers are limited to just one storage size option (64 GB) for their physical releases.

While not obvious from the start, Switch 2's single storage option of 64 GB has been influencing the decisions of several developers in a seemingly major way. Since the storage size offered exceeds the requirements of many games built for the platform, studios have had to opt for game-key cards instead to save costs. These game-key cards do not contain any game data but only the license to download the game digitally, which is the reason why a section of Nintendo fans has been up in arms over it since before the console's launch.

Switch 2 Cards May Get More Storage Options, Reducing the Need for Game-Key Cards

In what may be seen as a positive update, Macronix, a Taiwanese firm that apparently handles Nintendo's cartridge needs, reportedly stated that more storage options are on the way. Per UAnalyze (spotted by Twitter user SuperMetalDave64), the storage solutions company recently shared that its ROM products are "primarily used in Nintendo Switch game cartridges" and that, in the future, it will use in-house MLC NAND and outsourced 3D NAND components to provide "varying capacity requirements" for these cards. Given that different storage capacities already exist for the original Switch cards, it could be inferred that the aforementioned statement is talking about something similar becoming available for Switch 2 cards going ahead.

This development bears important significance in the context of the game-key card row. In recent months, even more game studios have opted for Nintendo's game-key cards, owing to the lack of smaller storage options for Switch 2 cartridges. The possibility of optimal storage options arriving in the future holds promise and could mark a changing trend where more developers put game data on the cartridge, instead of only a key for the game. On top of that, the unfavorable fan sentiment surrounding game-key cards further adds to the chances of such a shift taking place.

While most of Switch 2's innovations may have been well-received, the introduction of game-key cartridges has certainly not had the same kind of treatment. And, fortunately for the fans, Nintendo isn't letting this thing go unnoticed. As a matter of fact, the console giant has been conducting surveys across multiple markets, including Japan and the West, to record and assess what Switch 2 players think about game-key cards.
